bioghist.p: Founded in 1922, the Villanova School of Business offers seven undergraduate degrees in the fields of accounting, economics, and business administration; seven graduate programs; and an executive MBA program. Programs are accredited by the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB). The school is home to several business research centers including the Center for Marketing and Public Policy Research, the Center for Global Leadership, the Daniel M. DiLella Center for Real Estate, the Center for the Study of Church Management, the Center for Entrepreneurship, and the Institute for Research in Advanced Financial Technology.

scopecontent.p: The School of Business records include records of the Dean of the School and records of programs and departments within the school. The papers of the Dean of the School of Business are arranged into four series: Correspondence, Minutes, Reports, and Printed Materials. The bulk of the correspondence (1929-1978) is from faculty members or from the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB) regarding undergraduate accreditation. Minutes are present for Chairmen’s Meetings (1979-1990); Dean’s Council (1995-2006); and from several departments within the School of Business. The Reports series includes AACSB Undergraduate Accreditation applications and reports; a statement of the philosophy and objectives of the College of Commerce and Finance; annual Dean’s reports (1963-1987); annual reports from the College’s departments; proposals for a Master of Business Administration; and student and alumni surveys; accreditation questionnaires; self-study reports, and reports by consultants. Printed materials in the collection include syllabi for several College programs; and brochures for the Master of Business Administration program. The collection also includes syllabi from the Management Department, for courses given between 1982 and 1995 (with one syllabus from a Statistical Methods course given in 1971), and the Graduate Studies program, for courses given between 1983 and 1995.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
